magpie.data

Class MultiPropertyEntry

  • java.lang.Object
    • magpie.data.BaseEntry
      • magpie.data.MultiPropertyEntry
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable, java.util.Comparator
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CompositionEntry, ElementEntry

    public class MultiPropertyEntry
extends BaseEntry
    Entry that can have multiple properties. Consider these properties as potential class variables. This class simply allows a user to designate which property to use as the class variable, and seamlessly stores predictions of these properties internally.

    Users of entries that extend this class can designate a property as the class variable using setTargetProperty(int). Often, this is performed through various commands from the MultiPropertyDataset. You may notice that names of properties are not stored in this class, and they are actually stored in MultiPropertyDataset. This is to reminder users that they should access properties through the Dataset.

    If the "target" property is set to "-1", this class functions as a normal BaseEntry.

    See Also:
    MultiPropertyDataset, Serialized Form

      • setMeasuredProperties

        public void setMeasuredProperties(double[] newValues)
        Define the values of all measured properties of this entry. Simply use Double.NaN for all properties that have not been measured.

        This command will automatically reset the predicted properties, so use with caution.

        Parameters:
        newValues - Values of all measured properties

      • setMeasuredProperty

        public void setMeasuredProperty(int index,
                       double newValue)
        Set the measured value of a specific property of this entry. Use Double.NaN if it has not been measured (though I am not sure why you would do this).
        Parameters:
        index - Index of property to set
        newValue - New measured value
